ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learnt about different topical approaches to machine learning, including fairness, robustness, noisiness.

In this course, you learn about not only traditional methods in machine learning, but also how those traditional methods can go wrong with respect to society-held values. For instance, an ML method that optimizes accuracy may have a significant bias against certain groups or may be quite prone to adversarial attacks. This course focuses on how to balance accuracy with these other factors in constructing methodologies to learn from large datasets.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is very student led and interactive, which means that a lot of the learning will come out of the project and the amount of effort the student chooses to put into interacting with the instructor. I think the open nature of the course can also lead to ambiguity about the final deliverables, so more concrete examples would be helpful!

The format of the seminar, each lasting around two hours covering a distinct topic, was surprisingly engaging. Each provided a surface-level understanding of a series of topics, allowing for the students to delve deeper into a particular topic that they found interesting for their project. The format of the research project was also quite enjoyable, including weekly check-up meetings coupled with individual work over the course of the week. I really enjoyed the topics that the class covered as well as the delivery of those topics. The only weakness that comes to mind for this course is that the primary way for students to drill down a deeper understanding about topics that they were not presenting a project in was to read scholarly articles as opposed to having "mini-examples" to apply the topics themselves, although I recognize this is not easy to accomplish for a machine learning class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think we did as well as we could have on zoom!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Given that they are willing to put in the effort to research and take feedback regularly.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student at Yale. This class covers material that you wouldn't necessarily see in your typical computer science course at Yale, and especially with the movement towards ethical machine learning going on, I would highly recommend this to anyone who already has some experience in computer science and wants to see what "ethical ML" actually looks like.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
